awd_titl_txt: Synthesis and study of glycoconjugates and carbohydrate based macrocycles
awd_abstract_narration:
Carbohydrates are renewable and abundant natural resources. Using readily available sugars such as glucose, fructose, or lactose as building blocks, the research group of Professor Guijun Wang at Old Dominion University is developing new strategies for assembling sugars into large molecules with defined shape and functions. The resulting molecular systems are useful for understanding carbohydrate interactions with other biomolecules. Applications include the discovery of new catalysts and advanced biomaterials. The creation of novel, functional and biocompatible materials from abundant carbohydrates is important for the advancement of green chemistry, material sciences, and biomedical sciences. The project provides educational opportunities for students at all levels, especially undergraduate and graduate students. Students participate in interdisciplinary research in organic synthesis and bioorganic, medicinal, and materials chemistry. Graduate students have industrial internship opportunities in pharmaceutical companies.  
 
Low molecular weight gelators (LMWGs) can self-assemble and form reversible supramolecular gels, a category of soft materials with many applications. Professor Wang's group is developing synthetic methods to obtain several classes of glycomimetics that can form reversible hydrogels and organogels and other functional molecular assemblies. The main aims of the proposed research are: 1) The synthesis and study of new series of heterocycle functionalized sugar derivatives that may function as molecular gelators and ligands for catalysis. 2) The functionalization of effective molecular gelators or catalysts to improve their performance through formation of branched or linear oligomers. The multifunctional self-assembling systems are designed to retain the structural flexibility of LMWGs while also displaying mechanical strength and stability. 3) The synthesis and characterization of heterocycle-linked, carbohydrate-based macrocycles. These glycomacrocycles have important potential applications as novel catalysts or enzyme inhibitors.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit

With the NSF grant support, several milestones and discoveries in carbohydrate derived molecular systems have been achieved. We have prepared biocompatible supramolecular systems that are relevant to biomedical sciences and in the realm of smart materials. This has led to the discovery of a variety of effective molecular systems capable of gelation and possess desirable properties. The research has allowed better understanding of how carbohydrate derivatives form self-assembling supramolecular structures.  

The first area of accomplishment is the transformation of carbohydrate building blocks into useful materials that can form self-assembling systems, especially low molecular weight gelators (LMWGs). Using commonly available sugars such as glucose and glucosamine as the building blocks, a variety of advanced molecular systems have been prepared and analyzed. Major advances have been made in the rational design of sugar based gelators. We have established structure and gelation relationships which allow us and others to design smart hydrogels or organogels with a variety of applications.  

Additionally, we have incorporated stimuli-responsive functionality into our molecular systems, resulting in smart soft materials. Acid labile and pH sensitive functionalities were utilized to prepare smart materials capable of acid and base triggered gelation. Photoresponsive diacetylene glycolipids have been synthesized and the resulting colorless organogels were polymerized upon UV exposure to afford a red gel.  We have also synthesized photoswitchable diarylethenes based LMWGs which exhibited reversible color changes when exposed to different wavelengths of light. Several of our small sugar triazole and isoxazole derivatives were found to form gels in the presence of different metal ions, leading to novel supramolecular catalytic systems.  

The second main area focused on the creation of glycoclusters with well-defined structures and sizes in between small molecules and polymers. This is a pathway for discovering new materials with tunable physical and mechanical properties. The copper catalyzed azide alkyne cycloaddition reaction (CuAAC),  the “Click” reaction, is very import in the construction of various glycoconjugates. Using Click chemistry and simple sugars, we have prepared several series of glycoclusters with 2-6 arms. We found that typically 3 or 4 units of sugar triazoles will produce molecules with excellent gelation properties, while the hexameric derivatives efficiently accelerated Click reactions. A few glycoclusters formed stable gels with copper sulfate inside a column.  The resulting metallogels were used to run flow-like Click reaction. The system was found to be efficient over multiple cycles and reusable, reducing the overall waste of carrying out this chemistry. The discovery of the first gel columns composed of supramolecular metallogels that are reusable for CuAAC reaction is expected to impact multiple disciplines in the coming years. The knowledge resulting from this research in using dendritic glycoconjugates for effective catalysis provide a useful strategy, extending the research field from molecular self-assembly to catalysis and reactions.    

The third major accomplishment is on the synthesis of carbohydrate containing macrocycles. We have established methods for the scalable synthesis of sugar containing macrocycles. The methods can be used to prepare macrocycles with different ring sizes and functional groups. Carbohydrate-based macrocycles have found applications in drug discovery, molecular recognition, catalysis, and as advanced functional materials. Several different series of sugar-based macrocycles were synthesized and analyzed. The glycomacrocycles synthesized were used for the acceleration of certain Click reactions. The macrocycles can also be used as hosts for ion binding. These results contribute to the general fields of organic chemistry and catalysis, carbohydrate chemistry and supramolecular chemistry.

Broader Impact  

The discovery of tailored self-assembling glycomimetics that can perform specific tasks is very important for advancing our knowledge and benefitting society. We have developed new applications that use carbohydrates as building blocks for biocompatible functional materials. The research has impacted carbohydrate chemistry, supramolecular chemistry, materials sciences, analytical chemistry, and catalysts development. The photoresponsive derivatives can be useful as sensors for different biological environments, potentially for disease diagnosis. Several molecular gel systems were able to absorb for dyes dissolved in water, such as toluidine blue. These compounds are expected to be useful in environmental sciences for pollutant removal, heavy metal binding, and the solidification of oil.

The NSF support has resulted in seventeen peer-reviewed publications, including sixteen original research articles and one review. In addition, two book chapters were also published as part of the grant support. The research is highly interdisciplinary, allowing students to gain research experiences in organic synthesis, supramolecular chemistry, materials science, carbohydrate chemistry, etc.  A total of nine graduate students have participated in this research. These include five former students who have obtained PhD degrees, successfully moved on to future careers and contribute to industrial work force as highly skilled scientists. In addition, four REU students from community colleges and twelve undergraduate students received scientific training and participated in the research projects. We have also participated in multiple outreach events at local middle schools, high schools and with the general community.
